title: Pete Turner (musician)
text:
Peter James Turner (born August 1974), better known as Pete Turner, is a British musician and songwriter who has been the <a href="bassist">bassist</a> for the rock band <a href="Elbow%20%28band%29">Elbow</a> since the group's formation.
Biography.
Turner grew up in <a href="Bury%2C%20Greater%20Manchester">Bury</a>, <a href="Greater%20Manchester">Manchester</a> as an <a href="adopted%20child">adopted child</a> of <a href="White%20people">white</a> British parents. He has cited <a href="Adam%20and%20the%20Ants">Adam and the Ants</a> as the first band which he "really loved," and also cited <a href="Duran%20Duran">Duran Duran</a> and <a href="Public%20Enemy">Public Enemy</a> as early favourites. Turner has credited Duran Duran's <a href="John%20Taylor%20%28bass%20guitarist%29">John Taylor</a> as being his initial inspiration in becoming a bassist. He has also said that Public Enemy's record <a href="Fear%20of%20a%20Black%20Planet">Fear of a Black Planet</a> is his favourite album.
Turner was one of the three embryonic founders of what would later become Elbow, as he had formed a band named RPM with future Elbow members Richard Jupp and Mark Potter. Turner befriended future Elbow frontman <a href="Guy%20Garvey">Guy Garvey</a> at <a href="Bury%20College">Bury College</a> and the latter later joined RPM in 1991, triggering a band name change to Mr. Soft, and eventually later on first to just Soft and finally to Elbow in 1997.
Sometime in the <a href="2000s">2000s</a>, Turner relocated from Bury to Manchester's city centre, and then moved again to the suburban area of <a href="Chorlton-cum-Hardy">Chorlton</a> in Manchester's southern half in 2008.
